head.title: Build a Better Sandwich and . . . Yes! It's In!

hedline.hl1: Build a Better Sandwich and . . . Yes! It's In!

block.p: IN the course of human events, sandwiches have been maligned and exalted, have been delicate contrivances and overstuffed plebian affairs, alternately objects of desire and objects of scorn.

Either way, summer is high sandwich season. It is the season of hot dogs at the ball park, hamburgers by the backyard grill and French bread, pate and cheese at picnics -- and now, of leaner, post-modern constructions that rely more on roasted or marinated vegetables than meat and that stylishly recycle leftovers like grilled vegetables, lamb, chicken or fish.
IN the course of human events, sandwiches have been maligned and exalted, have been delicate contrivances and overstuffed plebian affairs, alternately objects of desire and objects of scorn.

Either way, summer is high sandwich season. It is the season of hot dogs at the ball park, hamburgers by the backyard grill and French bread, pate and cheese at picnics -- and now, of leaner, post-modern constructions that rely more on roasted or marinated vegetables than meat and that stylishly recycle leftovers like grilled vegetables, lamb, chicken or fish.

In fact, the nation is in the midst of a sandwich renaissance. There is a new public appetite for restrained rather than overstuffed sandwiches, born of health concerns rather than a fear of splatters and crumbs. Herb pestos, low-fat ricotta spreads and savory marmalades replace mayonnaise, dressings and butter; vegetables and grains supplant lunch meat, and artful salads take the place of the mandatory leaf of iceberg lettuce.

As recently as 12 years ago, James Beard, in describing his favorite bread construction -- round slices of brioche layered with parsley, onions and mayonnaise -- bridled at the term sandwich. "Sandwiches are so ordinary," he said; he called his invention "onion rounds."

The fast-food industry was probably a handmaiden to the sandwich's slip in status, and so, of course, was soft white bread, which until recent years reigned supreme in the American home and insured that every sandwich was a soggy sandwich.

But sandwiches have been creeping back up the social ladder. When Anne Rosenzweig reinvented the hamburger at the "21" Club five years ago, forming a patty around a pat of herb butter that added moisture and flavor, it shattered the proletarian image of the sandwich and paved the way for more imagination and whimsy.

In the sway of American regional cooking, restaurants along the Eastern Shore of Maryland proudly served crisp soft-shell crabs and lemon mayonnaise on sandwich rolls. Fried clam rolls got fresh herb tartar sauces and renewed cachet among Yankees. In New Orleans, fried oyster poor-boys were no longer simply the province of catering trucks on construction sites. Embellished with jalapeno mayonnaise or mounds of baby greens, they began to be served in fancy restaurants.
As sandwiches were getting better, a growing attitude of reverse snobbism -- the public doting on low-down chic -- improved the social image of sandwiches.

After all, in eras of genteel pretense, the fact that a sandwich must be eaten by hand made it suspect and gave rise to foppery like the Victorian era's crustless tea sandwiches, small enough to be consumed in one tidy nibble.

When politesse is eclipsed by romantic and earthy yearnings, people revel in the primitive satisfaction of hand-held meals, unpredictable crumbs, unruly tomatoes and dressings. Flaunting a disregard for cutlery, the public welcomes overstuffed heroes, club sandwiches and hot dogs dripping mustard and sauerkraut, whose effect on one's blouse or tie eventually pushes the preference back in the direction of delicate sandwiches. Neater sandwiches require a certain restraint in the eating, but they are easier on the wardrobe.

Though sandwiches satisfy, they are not a commitment to a full meal. They are to be eaten as offhandedly as they are out of the hand, so sandwiches suit the casual nature of summer and its distractions.

But their character also makes sandwiches vulnerable to being constructed as casually as they are meant to be eaten, which can result in sodden sandwiches or careless combinations in which oily mayonnaise, fatty dressings or butter is used like mortar.

In fact, bread should be dressed only enough to marry the soft underside of the bread or roll with the sandwich filling. By its flavor, a dressing or spread should complement the filling and subtly enhance the understated flavor of the bread. A soggy sandwich is a sorry affair. It robs the eater of the primal satisfaction of crunching through a crust, as well as the surprising contrast of textures in the fillings beneath the bread cover.

Sandwich times are good, again. Small focaccia topped with marinated zucchini, French bread stuffed with grilled vegetables and a sun-dried tomato ketchup, pita pockets layered with roasted eggplant and bulgur salad may not be as omnipresent as peanut butter and jelly, but these tasty sandwiches can be found in bakeries and carryout shops from Manhattan to Los Angeles.

The renewed popularity of sandwiches may also be a reaction to the phenomenon of diners sampling from the plates of fellow diners, with each entree considered fair game and each bite requiring comment. Whether lean and stylish or overstuffed, a sandwich will never be taken quite so seriously, and a sandwich remains one's own, to have and to hold. Pita Stuffed With Bulgur Wheat Salad and Eggplant Total time: 30 minutes 2 cups cooked bulgur wheat 1 tomato, chopped 2 scallions, chopped 3 tablespoons chopped parsley 1 tablespoon fresh lemon juice 1 1/2 teaspoons salt Freshly ground pepper to taste 8 slices grilled eggplant, halved 2 romaine lettuce leaves, torn 4 pita pockets, split in half.

Place the bulgur, tomato, scallions, parsley, lemon juice, salt and pepper in a mixing bowl, and toss to combine. Place 2 eggplant halves and some of the lettuce in each pita half. Spoon the salad between each eggplant half, and serve immediately.
Yield: 4 servings.

Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 220 calories, 1 gram fat, 0 milligrams cholesterol, 1,025 milligrams sodium, 8 grams protein, 45 grams carbohydrate. Greek Salad Sandwich Total time: 15 minutes 1 large tomato, chopped 1 cup pitted oil-cured black olives, coarsely chopped 1 cup thinly sliced red onion 4 teaspoons fresh lemon juice 3 cups shredded iceberg lettuce Freshly ground pepper to taste 1 cup crumbled feta cheese 4 pita pockets, split in half.
Place the tomato, olives, red onion, lemon juice, lettuce and pepper in a mixing bowl, and toss to combine. Toss in the feta. Divide the salad among the pita halves, and serve immediately.
Yield: 4 servings.

Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 270 calories, 13 grams fat, 25 milligrams cholesterol, 995 milligrams sodium, 10 grams protein, 30 grams carbohydrate. Grilled Vegetable and Mozzarella Sandwiches Total time: 45 minutes 3/4 cup sun-dried tomato spread (see recipe) 4 6-inch baguettes, split in half lengthwise 1/2 pound fresh mozzarella, sliced thin 2 portobello mushrooms, grilled and sliced thin 2 zucchini, cut lengthwise into 1/4-inch-thick slices and grilled 1 large eggplant, sliced lengthwise into 1/4-inch-thick slices, grilled and peeled, if desired. Salt and freshly ground pepper to taste.

Spread the sun-dried tomato mixture over both sides of each baguette. Divide the mozzarella among the baguettes. Season the mushrooms, zucchini and eggplant with salt and pepper and divide among the baguettes. Serve immediately.
Yield: 4 servings.

Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 710 calories, 35 grams fat, 45 milligrams cholesterol, 820 milligrams sodium (before salting), 25 grams protein, 80 grams carbohydrate. Lamb and Raw Artichoke Sandwiches Total time: 1 hour, 45 minutes 1/2 cup roasted garlic and onion jam (see recipe) 8 slices 7-grain bread 1/2 cup raw artichoke heart, sliced very thin 2 cups cooked lamb, sliced thin 1 cup minced watercress.

Spread the jam over half of the bread slices. Place the artichoke slices over the jam. Top with sliced lamb and watercress, dividing them equally among the four slices. Cover with the remaining bread slices, and serve immediately.
Yield: 4 servings.

Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 435 calories, 15 grams fat, 105 milligrams cholesterol, 360 milligrams sodium, 40 grams protein, 35 grams carbohydrate. Grilled Tuna and Black Olive Sandwiches Total time: 45 minutes 1/2 cup sun-dried tomato spread (see recipe) 8 slices sourdough bread 3 tablespoons chopped, pitted oil-cured olives 1 1/2 cups sliced grilled tuna.
Spread the sun-dried tomato spread over half of the bread slices. Sprinkle the olives evenly over the tomato spread. Top with tuna and a second slice of bread. Serve immediately.

Yield: 4 servings. Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 480 calories, 20 grams fat, 40 milligrams cholesterol, 445 milligrams sodium, 35 grams protein, 45 grams carbohydrate. Marinated Zucchini Sandwiches Total time: 45 minutes 2 tablespoons fresh lemon juice 1 teaspoon olive oil 2 teaspoons chopped fresh basil 3/4 teaspoon salt Freshly ground pepper to taste 2 large zucchini, thinly sliced lengthwise and cut in half crosswise 1 cup skim milk ricotta 2 scallions, chopped 2 tablespoons coarsely chopped, pitted oil-cured black olives 4 buns, split in half.

1. In a shallow dish, combine the lemon juice, olive oil, basil, 1/4 teaspoon of the salt and pepper. Bring a pot of water to a boil. Add the zucchini and blanch for 20 seconds. Drain, and place the warm zucchini in the lemon juice mixture. Marinate for 30 minutes.

2. Stir together the ricotta, scallions, black olives and remaining salt and pepper. Spread the mixture over each side of each bun. Drain the zucchini, and divide among the bottom halves of each bun. Cover with the top of each bun, and serve immediately.

Yield: 4 servings. Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 235 calories, 9 grams fat, 20 milligrams cholesterol, 675 milligrams sodium, 11 grams protein, 30 grams carbohydrate. Southwestern Chicken Salad On Corn and Black-Pepper Biscuits Total time: 40 minutes For the biscuits: 1 cup all-purpose flour 1/2 cup cornmeal 1 1/2 teaspoons baking powder 3/4 teaspoon salt 1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper 6 tablespoons cold, unsalted butter, cut in pieces 6 tablespoons milk For the salad: 1 cup sliced grilled chicken 1/2 cup grilled corn 1/2 cup diced roasted red pepper 2 scallions, sliced thin 2 teaspoons chopped fresh cilantro 1/2 jalapeno pepper, seeded and minced 1 teaspoon olive oil 1 teaspoon fresh lime juice 1/2 teaspoon salt Freshly ground pepper to taste.

1. To make the biscuits, preheat oven to 425 degrees. Sift the flour, cornmeal, baking powder, salt and pepper into a mixing bowl. Add the butter, and combine until mixture resembles coarse meal. Gently stir in the milk. Turn the dough out onto a lightly floured board, and knead a few times until smooth. Pat the dough out to a thickness of 1/2 inch. Use a 3-inch round cookie cutter to cut out 4 biscuits, patting out the scraps. Place the biscuits on a parchment-lined baking sheet, and bake until lightly browned, about 15 minutes. Let cool.

2. While the biscuits are baking, make the salad by tossing all ingredients together in a mixing bowl. Cut the biscuits in half with a serrated knife. Fill with the chicken salad, and serve immediately.
Yield: 4 servings.

Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 435 calories, 20 grams fat, 80 milligrams cholesterol, 850 milligrams sodium, 15 grams protein, 40 grams carbohydrate. Sun-Dried Tomato Spread Total time: 30 minutes 1/2 pound oil-packed, sun-dried tomatoes, drained, oil reserved 3 tablespoons hot water 2 cloves roasted garlic 1/4 roasted onion 10 large basil leaves 1 teaspoon balsamic vinegar.

Place the sun-dried tomatoes in a food processor and chop. Add 1 tablespoon of the reserved oil plus the hot water, garlic, onion, basil and vinegar. Process until smooth, stopping as needed to scrape sides of bowl. Scrape into a small container and keep refrigerated.

Yield: 1 cup. Roasted Garlic And Onion Jam Total time: 1 hour, 15 minutes 2 large onions, unpeeled 1 head garlic, unpeeled, smashed to separate cloves slightly 2 tablespoons olive oil Pinch cayenne pepper 1/8 teaspoon salt, plus more to taste.

1. Preheat oven to 350 degrees. Place the onions and garlic in a casserole and brush with the olive oil. Cover with aluminum foil. Bake until onions and garlic are very soft when pierced with a knife, about 1 hour.

2. When they are cool enough to handle, push the garlic cloves and onions from their skins, and place in a food processor. Add the cayenne and salt, and process until smooth. Taste, and adjust seasoning if desired. Store in an airtight container.
Yield: 1 cup.
